newsitem.title: USA: ADM expansion continues with UGG stake.
newsitem.headline: ADM expansion continues with UGG stake.

text.p: U.S. food processing giant Archer Daniels Midland Co added another key global partner Thursday with its agreement to buy 45 percent of Canada's second largest grain handler, analysts said.

"Archer is very successfully expanding. Their ability to manage any type of grain-related facility is very good, so it looks like a win-win situation," said Leonard Teitelbaum, a Merrill Lynch food and agribusiness analyst.
United Grain Growers Ltd said earlier Thursday it agreed to a C$113 million deal under which ADM will acquire a 45 percent stake in the Canadian company.
"Archer gets a good solid partner, UGG gets some cash and some management should they need it," Teitelbaum said.

Earlier this month ADM agreed with Glencore Grain Holding to buy Glencore's grain facilities in Brazil and Paraguay, while last year ADM acquired Minneapolis based grain merchandising firm Benson-Quinn.

"Their (ADM's) strength has always been to strategically locate grain sourcing, grain storage and grain processing facilities and this looks like that pattern being continued," Teitelbaum of Merrill Lynch said.
Tim Ramey, an analyst with Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, also saw the move as a continuation of ADM's expansion strategy.
"It looks like a logical extension of their reach," he said.

ADM is one of the largest wheat millers in North America and already owns, leases or has a 50 percent or larger interest in 10 flour mills in Canada. UGG had 173 primarily grain elevators across Canada's Prairies as of July 31, 1996.
"It is a backyard type of alliance for them (ADM)," Ramey said. "It is a business they are already in, a business they understand."
